If she is not willing to consider your explanation and if she is not willing to continue working with you, she still has an ethical obligation to provide you with referral resources to another therapist.

question: I think I have depression, anxiety, bipolar disorder, and I have anger issues. I told my mom over and over again. She told me she would get me a therapist, but she never did. I just found out that my mom can't afford a therapist for me.
answer: It can be difficult to get counseling if you don't feel supported by family members. There might be a few options. If you are in school, I'd recommend talking to a school counselor or school nurse. They often will be able to help you access free or affordable counseling resources in your community. In addition, depending on where you live, it's also often possible to call 211 for referrals to free or low cost counseling services in your area.I'd encourage you not to give up. You are on the right track.

question: I have major depression, severe, PTSD, anxiety disorder, and personality disorder. I had an appointment with my doctor. I was very upset, and I shared with him about that particular drug.
answer: Your doctor might be required to tell your psychiatrist - especially if your doctor is concerned about your safety.It was definitely a good thing that you told your primary care physician about what is going on. I know that must have been difficult to talk about with him. By having that conversation, you are helping your primary care physician and your psychiatrist work together to best support your health.

question: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?
answer: There are typically three reasons why therapy is terminated:1) Client has met therapy goals2) Client is not progressing 3) Therapist is not a good fit for clientIn order to properly assess whether therapy is helping and what progress is being made, the therapist needs to have ways of consistently checking in with clients sessions-by-session to determine what is helping, what isn't, and where the client is at in relation to their original therapy goals. When a client has met their goals, that is a good time to end counselling sessions unless the client has new goals or simply wants to check-in periodically to make sure that they are still on track (sometimes referred to as relapse prevention). When a client is not progressing, and feedback has been taken and attempts have been made to make the therapy more helpful for the client but to no avail, than it is considered unethical to continue to work with the client. In these circumstances, referring out to another therapist who may be a better fit is a good idea.

question: My therapist is gay so there are no sexual issues here. However, my therapist for six years has made me believe that he cares about me and that we are friends. I have loaned money to him many times, and he always paid me back. I had a medical emergency last weekend and I was heavily medicated. I knew that this therapist came into my home and wrote down my credit card information so he could pay back what he owed me, but this therapist dropped me off and never came again. I don't know what to do.
answer: I'm sorry to hear that this has happened. Counselors are legally and ethically required to make sure that they always put the wellbeing of their clients above their own interests. In addition, counselor ethical rules, and the laws in just about every state, make it illegal for counselors to take advantage of a client financially. A counselor borrowing money from a client (even if the counselor pays it back) would usually be considered to be taking advantage of the client.There are a few options you have at this point if you can't (or don't want) to continue to try to contact him directly. You can file a complaint with your states' regulatory board and let them know what has happened. An investigator will then look into the situation for you. Another option would be for you to find a different counsleor who can provide you with an independent and netural point of view to help you figure out how you want to handle this situation.

question: I just wanted to get to know one so I can hear about their college experience and the courses they took. I also wanted to know if they enjoy their job and how long they were in school.
answer: It's a great idea for you to reach out to find a psychologist to talk to if this is a field you might be interested in pursuing. Regarding the length of schooling, it generally takes 4 years of college and an additional 4 to 7 years of graduate school to earn a doctorate degree to become a psychologist. There are also other similar professions, including counseling that don't require a doctorate degree. Licensed counselors generally completed 4 years of college and an additional 2 years of graduate school. If you are thinking about a career in psychology, the local APA chapter would be a good place to start to find a local psychologist to talk to. Here's a link to the NJ APA chapter:https://www.psychologynj.org/

question: I am an international student, and it is my first semester in graduate school in the United States. I faced a cultural shock, and I was so depressed when I arrived here. My counselor in the university was my savior. He helped me a great deal. Now I am going back to my country for a vacation. I was thinking to get him something special with my country's name on it, and I remembered that he likes wine. My country is known for that. Is it appropriate to give him wine as a gift after Christmas?
answer: This is a great question. In general it is not appropriate for counselors to accept gifts from their clients. There are some exceptions to this general rule - including a recognition that there may be a valid cultural aspect to this type of gift giving.It might be best to simply offer your counselor a holiday card as an expression of your feelings. You could also talk to your counselor about the gift and ask if him it if would be appropriate.In the end, I know he would most appreciate just knowing how much the counseling meant to you.

question: I have an eating disorder of binging. I've had gastric sleeve surgery. I need help with issues of abuse as a child, addiction, and abusive men. I have been in therapy for five months and get no feedback from my therapist.
answer: It can be really frustrating to feel like your counselor is not providing you with the help you need.My recommendation in a situation like this would be to let your counselor know how you feel. Specifically tell Your counselor that you don't seem to be getting the amount of feedback you would like.If this doesn't help, then you might want to look for another counselor who will be a better fit for you.

question: I'm worried I should see a therapist due to past events and current mental status. I'm just so unsure of how to ask my doctor about seeing someone.
answer: Having this kind of conversation with a doctor can feel difficult. But remember, you are the expert on you. Any good medical professional will recognize that.You are absolutely right to think about the importance of being your own health care advocate. Generally, the best approach is simply to be honest. Let your doctor know what you are concerned about and tell your doctor what you think might help. If there is a specific issue that you‚Äôd like to address in counseling, let you doctor know about it. And don‚Äôt hesitate to directly ask for a referral.I know this may all feel a little overwhelming. It might help to bring a family member or significant-other with you to provide support when you talk to your doctor. It‚Äôs great that you‚Äôve already taken this first step to reach out. You‚Äôre on the right track.

question: I need help dealing with stress. How can I handle it all and feel less stressed out?
answer: How can we handle stress in healthy ways? Eat and drink to optimize your health. Some people try to reduce stress by drinking alcohol or eating too much. Try and find if you do certain things or are there triggers when you do. Exercise regularly. In addition to having physical health benefits, exercise has been shown to be a powerful stress reliever. ... Stop using tobacco and nicotine products. People who use nicotine often refer to it as a stress reliever. ... Study and practice relaxation techniques. Taking the time to relax every day helps to manage stress and to protect the body from the effects of stress. Lastly channel your creative energy try my adult coloring book it might help

question: I need help knowing how to deal with stress. What can I do?
answer: What are five ways to reduce stress?Here Are 5 Important And Effective Ways To Reduce Stress And Anxiety 1. Practice deep breathing exercises 2. Just lie down on the floor 3. Focus on an object to help calm your breathing 4. Take a break and listen to some music 5. Smile even when you don‚Äôt feel like smiling üòÉ

question: I'm in my late 20s. I have two jobs right now, I'm in school, and I feel like I just have a lot under my belt right now. I get stressed out really easily. I tend to worry and over-think. I'm just worried about money and everything.
answer: A good start is to pay attention to some basic issues: sleep, nutrition, exercise and socially supportive relationships. A great car on an empty tank will not get you very far.

question: Is it a type of fetish, or is it normal?
answer: Maybe it is a way to secretly satisfy your own wish to be or to live life gay.

question: I am a young adult, and I was sexually assaulted by an older man when I was a teenager (which has really intensified the guilt/shame). However, I've been attracted to much older men since I was even younger than that.
answer: Sometimes the reason for being attracted to older men is because of growing up with a father who was distant.If you grew up having enough interaction with your dad to know you'd have liked more and didn't receive this, then maybe your longings of childhood are still active within you.It is ok to like older men.Just be sure you're not idealizing them, or anyone else.Because regardless of age, a relationship is based on who the two people really are, not how we'd like imagining them.

question: I have been experiencing a lot of sexual tension with a lot of the guys that I talk to nowadays. I keep imagining having sex with them. I have never had sex before, nor have I had a boyfriend. I feel lonely and empty. I feel like my body is not okay, and I am missing something. I talk to so many boys in school, and I always fantasize about half of them. I want this feeling to stop because it is interfering with my time to study since most of the time, I am busy thinking about sex.
answer: Hi Montreal, I'm glad you wrote. What you're experiencing is normal. We're sexual beings. We have a built-in desire to connect sexually with others, because it feels good, to keep procreation going, and mostly to "connect" with other people, because connecting with others makes us feel fulfilled and valuable. Sexual desire is a healthy part of you. Maybe your body is telling you it wants to dive into that water and taste it instead of just staring at it? It sounds like you're beginning to explore yourself sexually, and that's okay.At your young age, you also have another innate burning desire, and that is to know yourself. I see both of these desires burning and competing in you. It's a bit of a crazy time...you want to connect with others but you're not sure who you are or what you want from them. You want to know yourself but you can't learn about yourself in a vacuum. It's okay to trust your instincts. It's okay to connect sexually with others, as long as you're preventing disease and pregnancy and you know how to protect your boundaries. But even as I write this, I think maybe I'm being controlling and overprotective of you; it's your body and you're in charge of what happens to it! (But I do want you to be safe...whatever that means to you). Maybe talk to someone you trust. With each encounter you have with other people (sexual or not), you will learn more about yourself and what you want, both sexually and just in relationship or friendship. You will develop a sense of who you are.Have you tried to get to know yourself sexually? This is a super place to start, and knowing how your own body works can give you confidence when you eventually connect with others. When you explore your own body, what feels good? What brings you to orgasm? I wish you well as you explore both who you are and how it feels to connect with others safely. :)

question: Back in high school, my friend and I used to masturbate around each other. I hate even talking about it now because it's so weird. We didn't even realize how messed up it was at the time. One time, it escalated and we ended up doing it for each other. It wasn't supposed to be a gay thing, but it sure sounds like it now that I talk about it. I pushed this away until it recently came up in my head again. I'm having a lot of trouble.
answer: Writing about your high school masturbation times with your friend, is itself a form of acknowledging the full picture of who you are. You are doing well to reflect on your actions in the truthful way you are doing.Also positive is that you have perspective, that at your age and social maturity, you were innocently doing something that in adult terms, would be considered in a negative way.Maybe through your more mature mind's eye of today, you can feel some compassion and understanding for your high school self. This way your sense of self-judgment may start to dissolve a little bit more.

question: Every time I send a message to someone or a group message on Instagram, iMessage, or snapchat people will read my messages but then they won't answer me. Could it be that there is something they don't like about me? I don't understand why they won't answer my messages. How do I get people to respond to me?
answer: You are not alone. SocIal media marketing is and can be tricky. Today to feel validated it is to receive a like , comment or follow. When friends or family members are interacting on their pages but not yours it can be frustrating. Law of Attraction might help. Contact me or visit my profile to learn more.

question: These "jokes" are made about everything. They seem to have the need to say something "funny" about everything. It's not funny, just awkward.
answer: I agree, it is awkward when people make jokes about subjects which may not be funny at all. And, if a person only jokes, then after laughing and realizing the person has nothing of themselves to offer, this can also be quite tedious.Realize that you are more aware of human interaction having many levels of expression. You could start avoiding people who irritate you by the way they behave.

question: It's really hard to not have negative feelings about friends who don't put any effort into nourishing our relationship.
answer: One thing I would ask is "why are you still hanging with those {friends}?" A relationship needs to be nurtured by both parties, it is a dynamic fluctuation between two people. I would ask you to question why you continue to remain together as friends, I always believed that a relationship should emit positivity towards all parties involved, if your in a relationship that is one-sided, it is inevitable that it will start to de-compensate. Never travel with the circus, never travel with fools, everything in life should have some positive payout, will things at times be negative, of course they will, but in order to keep something or someone in your life there should be more positivity than negativity.Hope this helps, C

question: Because we are on opposite coasts, we try to talk early mornings, but she is constantly interrupted by visitors. I suggested setting aside some time, but she has made it very clear she has no intention of changing her lifestyle. She is also drinking beer every day on antipsychotics.
answer: The answer depends on how satisfied and happy you feel in being part of this friendship.From what you write, there aren't any statements as to what gives you happiness about being a friend to this person.Since you already made a request of. your friend and she isn't following through, you could ask if she is willing to work with your suggested plan.The friendship may take a new format, depending on your friend's response.Its possible to be in contact more spontaneously, when either of you feel like contacting the other.What matters most is your own dissatisfaction with the current relationship status.Even if you change to a, birthday and holiday only conversation, or some other style of interacting, at least it will be the result of the effort from each person, not just one, who is you, designing arrangements which only you are willing to keep.

question: My best friend and I were pranking her friend, and I told her to tell him that she likes him. She said no, but I forced her. After she told him, he told her that he likes her too. Their friendship is ruined because of me. She won't forgive me, and I feel really guilty. I feel like crying.
answer: In order for your friend to forgive you she'd need to trust you understand the damage you introduced into her relationship with her friend.Its possible if you offer your friend expressions of your empathy toward her over an extended time, possibly she'll forgive you.You're certainly learning relationship lessons on how to treat people and the effect of betraying another person, which will last forever.Maybe this was meant to be the outcome.

question: I was ‚Äúmentored‚Äù by this guy for a few years spiritually. It was okay at times, but other times, it was just weird. I try not to think about it too much, but a lot of manipulation and lying happened, yet no one else really believed me when I told them. It's like he's two different people, and no one else really sees that side of him. I was blamed for a lot of our troubles, and now we don't really talk much. I'm worried because he's in a trusted position of leadership and no one suspects anything. They just think I'm attacking his character. How do I know for sure?
answer: You may intuitively be sensing what many professionals in the social sciences and psychology have already understood.Just Google "psychopaths and leadership" and many articles come up about boardroom politics and that psychopaths are very successful in these roles.Theoretically, is it terrible that corporate leadership qualities match those of psychopaths? Well, yes. And, I consider your question as a mark of your sensitive awareness toward other people. Being able to recognize social dynamics, is a strength that you have.Psychopaths know how to be charming and to twist words so that others believe that their own interest is the same as the psychopath's.I agree with you about not being able to change people's minds who are attached to this person's interactions.The only way you can introduce a change in the relationship system of a psychopath is that if you are aware of illegal or law breaking activity, and you have evidence of this, that you contact relevant authorities.No one is allowed to break laws, including psychopaths.

question: She mostly targets me on social media. The bullying used to be much worse, but it is still going on. The comments are so vague, but I know that they are meant for me. Even when I confront her, she messages me short phrases to try to get in my head. If I try to fight back, she will ruin me.
answer: Sorry to hear of your problem situation. Feeling intimidated by another person is very unsettling.Stop having contact with the person.Bullies only interact with others either by intimidating someone or by themselves feeling intimidated by someone.Bullies do not have the same dynamics as everyone else.No one can convince or persuade or talk a bully out of their behavior.The best protection for yourself, assuming you are not being physically threatened by the person, is to close contact with them.This does not take away any of the disappointment or sadness of wishing for a better relationship with the person.Until the bully wants to interact differently with others, only harm can result from contact with them.Step one is to stop the bleeding, then to assess and learn to live with not having the person in your life.

question: I'm having problems shutting them out and putting up walls.
answer: It sounds like you would like to let other people get close to you and at the same time you are finding yourself compelled to keep people at a distance. Often times, when we have difficulty trusting others, it is because we have specific fears about what would happen if we get close or let our guard down. Such fears may be rooted in past experiences in relationships in which we were hurt and or disappointed. In working with a therapist, you can gain insight into what is underneath your compulsion to put walls around yourself and develop ways to form authentic, lasting, satisfying relationships with others.

question: I'm having a quincea√±era, and the girls don't like their dresses. They never told me, and now it's a week away. I don't know what to do.
answer: How did you find out that the girls aren't happy with their dresses?Did you hear this directly from one of them or is this third hand information that someone else told you about one of the girls in your party?The answer matters because gossiping instead of directly telling you about a problem, is a problem in itself.I suggest a conversation with the entire group of girls in which you tell them how you actually are feeling about their opinions about the dresses.One topic you may consider bringing up is what everyone expects to get out of the party. Are they coming because they like one another and wearing a dress in which the girl is happy, is only one way of having fun together?You may learn a great deal as to the difference in values about a quincea√±a among you and your friends.I hope you'll have a fun party!

question: I would like to be able to have more positive relationships in the present.
answer: Staying present is an attitude most of us aspire to, and most of us have to work at it‚Äîcertainly at first. I‚Äôm here to tell you that living in the now or being mindful is a skill anyone can learn. Unfortunately, the only way to do it is to do it. What a paradox! But there are plenty of other skills that we are not born with: walking on stilts, riding a bike, swimming, and driving a car are good examples. You can‚Äôt learn them by reading about them.Having said that, I can recommend two books on the subject: Eckhart Tolle‚Äôs The Power of Now and David Richo‚Äôs When the Past is Present. Richo asks that we don‚Äôt beat ourselves up about dwelling on past events. This is nature‚Äôs way of reminding us that we have unfinished business. But while we are attended to the wounds and confusion that litter our earlier lives, we can prepare to inhabit the expanded present that awaits us.He offers three helpful steps to making any important life change:Step One: Hold in awareness the behavior, belief, attitude, or characteristic you want to change in yourself and how you want to be different. Awareness is the opposite of distraction and stuffing.Step Two: Live as if you have already made the change. (This is hard and takes courage, but you can do it. Ride that bike‚Äîeven if for a foot or two.)Step Three: Be persistent. (Practice, practice, practice.)Just as two-year-olds are able to walk confidently after hundreds of hours of practice, you‚Äôll be able to stay in the here and now as long as you want after trying and failing many, many times.

question: In this argument my friends are all against me so I'm wondering if I'm exaggerating my feelings. I feel like I'm being attacked and that is making me blow things out of proportion and taking the role of the victim, when in reality I'm the one being unreasonable and I am simply annoying my reasonable friends. Or are they really being insensitive and not respecting me in our friendship?
answer: Conflict is a tricky beast and shows up in every one of our relationships. What I'm reading is that you find yourself in a loop of seeking validation of your thoughts and feelings from your friends rather than validating yourself. Am I right? If you aren't validating yourself, no one else will be able to either. Try finding a small nugget of truth in the feedback your friends give you, this will help to lower your defenses and help your friends hear what you are really sharing. And then if you are still feeling vulnerable, share that too...

question: They're calling me names like hypocrite and a baby even when they act in the same manner as I do. I'm tired of being called names. What should I do?
answer: It sounds like your confused as to why your friends would be calling you a hypocrite when they act in the same manner, correct? Communication is key to any relationship. I would recommend speaking with your friends face-to-face to address why they feel your behavior is concerning. In-person contact is the best method of sorting out differences considering texts, emails or any written response can be misconstrued. Be upfront with them and let them know that being accused of hypocrisy is hurtful and you feel it is unfounded. If after speaking with them you feel that they have valid reasons for the way they are feeling, maybe you can consider modifying your behavior accordingly. Especially if this friendship is valuable to you. However, make sure they are aware that there is a respectful way to address these issues and name calling is not one of them. On the other hand, if you feel that their reasons are indeed unfounded, it may be best to distance yourself from the relationship. Not all friendships are healthy ones. And it is important that you surround yourself with people who are an asset to your self esteem as opposed to those that hinder it.I hope you are able to get this matter sorted. Best of luck!

question: I nanny a three year old. When he wakes up in the morning he calls out for someone to come get him. If I am the one to go get him out of bed he gets really upset and refuses to let me near him. He screams that he wants his mom or dad (they work from home). The rest of the day he loves me. But not in the mornings. What can I do?
answer: It seems like you are being extra hard on yourself here! The behavior he exhibits is pretty normal for a three year-old. Sounds like he may feel more emotionally dysregulated upon waking and wants one of his love sources to help him stabilize that. It's probably more instinctual and not personal to you.Give yourself some credit for how things are the rest of the day---that's information that you've done well. You even describe that he "loves" you! That's huge!Either way, I'm sure it's jarring to go through that in the mornings. Is there a routine you use to help him make that transition? I don't know what his parents' rules are, but there could be some ways to incorporate some predictable structure. Maybe that means his favorite toy/stuffed animal paired with his favorite cartoon. You seem very caring, so it's probably likely you are already offering some compassionate response to his upset. It may help to have him take a couple deep breaths with you if he's able to help self-regulate. He may not be responsive to that and that's OK. Either way, it sounds like this is only happening upon waking.Another thought--do his parents know this is happening? Maybe they have some ideas about how to help soothe him or perhaps they have some strategies they can use the night before (e.g., talking to him about the emotions of the morning hours). Let yourself off the hook though--you seem to be doing a wonderful job with this kiddo!

question: I've been bullied for years and the teachers have done nothing about it. I haven't been diagnosed with depression, but i have been extremely sad for years. How can I deal with being bullied at school when the teachers won't help?
answer: That's a very difficult situation that you are in. But you are not alone. I have several school-aged clients who find little to no assistance from their teachers at their schools regarding bullying.There are a few options that are available to you to help deal with being bullied at school. One option that I would suggest is for you to talk to your support network. Friends and family can sometimes be good sources of support. Another option would be to speak with us about your counselor, if you have one. And third, there are some excellent online sources of support regarding the bullying at school (www.stopbullying.org).

question: I need to get on base to see my doctor. My ID card was in my wallet which was stolen. I‚Äôm unable to reach my husband at this time. He is only one who can take me on base in order to get a new ID so I can continue to see doctor. Is there anything I can do?
answer: You should be able to get a replacement ID card either from the Personnel Office on your local base (the actual name of this office will vary depending on which branch of the military it is). You may also be required to go to the Military Police or Security office on base to report the loss of your old ID card.

question: I keep having these random thoughts that I don't want. Things like "you aren't worth anything." I know they're my own thoughts but it feels like someone else is saying it. What is wrong with me, and how can I stop having these thoughts?
answer: I think we all go through a period of time where we think we aren't worth anything. Sometimes these feelings are a result of low self esteem or because of shame. The most important part of dealing with this thought is to separate feelings from reality. "I don't feel worth anything, but I know what I do is important, I know who I am matters to others. I know I am loved and cared about."When you find yourself having these thoughts, stop, take a few deep breaths and try to reframe what you're thinking.

question: How do therapists classify the type of personality their clients have? What characteristics do they look at to decide what type of personality the client has? I've read about this online, but I'd like to understand this from a therapist's point of view.
answer: This is a great question, and I am happy to have the opportunity to explain my approach. When I am determining what type of personality a client has, I take my time and really absorb their lens/ point of view to themselves and others. Determining a personality type takes some time getting to know the person, and building rapport. After taking time to get to know them, and learning about their view they have of themselves and others, it is important to pick-up on more specific personality traits, which comprehensively contribute to a personality type. Clinicians, including myself, often witness certain traits that are enduring and consistent, which indicate a type of personality. For example, if a therapist is noticing that a client is exhibiting traits of organization, needing to be on time, planning, and perfectionism, these traits contribute to the "type A personality". In addition to utilizing clinical judgment, clinicians often use personality assessments and follow the guidelines of the DSM-5/ ICD-10.

question: I empathize so much, even with characters on tv or in video games, that I actually feel physical pain. This has made life difficult to say the least. I believe I have an actually case of something called hyper empathy disorder. But since it's such a new disorder I can't find any information about it. Could this be what is going on with me?
answer: Sometimes it's helps to have a name for a problem - it can make you feel less alone as in, "oh there's a name for this and other people have this experience too." On the other hand naming the problem can also make it stick around longer as in "now I have a special problem that has a special name, and that's an important part of who I am."Bottom line, whether it's a disorder or not, you would like life to be easier and not have to be pulled so much by other people's energy and feelings. You might want to try imagining that you have a volume dial on your empathy (just like the volume dial or button on the tv) that you can gently turn down to the point where you still feel what's going on but it's not so "loud". You can also try imagining pulling your own energy back as if you were drawing your energy back home to the center of your own body and being, letting go of the other people or characters that pulled your energy out so far. This is a way create better boundaries and protect your own vulnerability. Just like on an airplane where they tell you to put on your own oxygen mask first before helping anyone else, your empathy will most likely not really help others if you allow yourself to be depleted.

question: How do you know you have the right therapist for you? How would I know how to "train" my therapist to be able to give me what I need from treatment?
answer: Finding the right therapist for you is very important and can sometimes be tricky. It can sometimes take a number of sessions to get a good sense of whether you and your therapist are the "right fit." The first couple of sessions are generally spent on gathering information, formulating a plan of treatment, and building the client/therapist relationship. The client/therapist relationship will be very different from other relationships you have experienced. You will know you have found the right therapist when you notice there is a good rapport between the two of you. You will get a sense that the therapist "gets you" and understands the issues being presented. If you feel that you can trust your therapist and feel comfortable opening up and providing feedback during your sessions then you know it is a good fit. In terms of "how to train your therapist how to give you what you need from treatment" the therapeutic relationship is collaborative so the two of you will be working together as a team. During your sessions, the goal is for you to feel comfortable giving feedback about what is working and what is not working in your sessions. When you express your needs to your therapist then the two of you will discuss the best ways to get those needs met in order to maximize the effectiveness of your sessions.

question: Is it normal for people to cry during therapy, or is it just me?
answer: Absolutely it's normal to cry in therapy sessions. Sometimes clients have stories they never shared with anyone or never said out loud and that results to crying. Crying is a normal reaction to feeling hurt or sad or sometimes angry. I welcome all crying to my therapy room.

question: Does counseling really do anything that can help people?
answer: Yes, Counseling provides an area for people to speak to an unbiased professional about their concerns to address their unique needs. While length of time varies, counseling is a process and can be done from as little as one session to multiple sessions. Counseling provide a safe, non-judgmental, empathetic atmosphere from a professional helper provide the service

question: How does a person start the counseling process?
answer: Hello, There are many ways to approach a counselor and starting the process, however they all start with picking up the phone. It's most definitely an uncomfortable feeling, but once that first step is taken it is often met with a wave of relief. My recommendation is always to call and speak with a therapist over the phone before scheduling an appointment. Listening to how they converse, use their tone and inflection, may give you a brief insight to how they will respond to you and increase your comfort right away. You may also discover, rather quickly, that this therapist is not the right match for you.Regardless of how you go about it, I like to remind all people who call, email, text or walk-in, therapists are a bit like pizzas - if you don't like the toppings, send it back! There are hundreds of therapists offering all kinds of styles of therapy - take the time to pick one that suits you.

question: After first meeting the client, what is the process that a counselor facilitates?
answer: I think this question can vary based on the individual therapist, their style and theoretical orientation. Clients are always welcome to ask questions before and during the process to understand their care. When I am first meeting with a client I take a more formalized approach in our first session completing what is called a psychosocial assessment. Typically I explore what brought the client to therapy in the first place and I take a more direct approach asking a variety of questions related to the specific struggles, frequency, history, duration, etc. This is NOT how my normal therapy sessions are and I try to explain that to my clients so they understand that while my first initial sessions is a lot of information gathering, and me typing out their responses, on going therapy is very client focused and catered to the needs of the client.

question: What are the basic skills a good counselor needs to have?
answer: Some basic skills are empathy, you should feel heard and understood. The therapist should keep the focus on you since counseling is about you and the issues your facing. That being said if you feel like they are sharing too much it‚Äôs going okay to say this. They should also be able to identify some coping skills to help you manage the symptoms your experiencing.

question: What are some difficulties that a counselor can encounter when dealing with a client?
answer: Each client brings their own style they like to a coaching or counseling relationship. When I counseled and coached military I learned to relate to what style of coaching they seek. Some were better at the Drill Sergeant style of coaching, or a liberal style, integrative, humanistic, progressive, or conservative. Some can be obsessed and try and cross the line. When you are in the public eye it can be a bit much and you have to know what client is a good fit for your practice. Some don't see you as human but we are. We seek to do the best we can with our knowledge cause it is a calling and I am sure others will say on here that we have to have our go to place of healing also so we can be good for our clients.

question: I'm a young adult in my first office job. My manager has been so critical and demanding lately that I broke down in the stairwell yesterday. I tried to address it with him today, but my voice cracked and I got emotional. I'm terrified this makes me look unprofessional and that I'll be let go.
answer:
Thank you for sharing this with me. What you're describing sounds incredibly difficult and painful. First, I want to validate what you're feeling: the stress of a critical manager, the fear of job loss, and the frustration of becoming emotional during a conversation you hoped to handle calmly are all completely understandable reactions. Many people in their first professional roles have experienced similar moments of overwhelm‚Äîyou are not alone in this.

It‚Äôs important to recognize that becoming emotional does not make you unprofessional. It makes you human. Showing emotion in a high-stress situation is a natural response, not a character flaw. The fact that you gathered the courage to address the issue directly with your manager speaks to your professionalism and commitment.

From a practical standpoint, let's consider some next steps. First, prioritize your well-being. The breakdown in the stairwell is a signal that your stress levels are unsustainable. Please be kind to yourself this evening. In the coming days, you might consider requesting a follow-up meeting with your manager. You could frame it by saying, "I'd like to continue our conversation from yesterday. I value my role here and want to ensure I'm meeting expectations." This reframes the interaction around your performance and goals, rather than the emotional moment.

If the criticism feels excessive or personally targeted, please document specific instances. This is for your own clarity. Also, explore if your company has an HR department or an Employee Assistance Program (EAP) that offers confidential counseling‚Äîthis is exactly the type of situation they can help you navigate.

Your feelings of fear are real, but remember that one emotional moment is rarely grounds for termination, especially when you are proactively seeking solutions. Your well-being is paramount. If these feelings of anxiety persist or intensify, I strongly encourage you to seek support from a mental health professional who can provide ongoing guidance tailored to you. You took a brave step by reaching out here, and that same strength will help you navigate this challenge.

question: I'm a college student working part-time in retail. After a particularly harsh shift where my supervisor publicly berated me, I had to hide in the stockroom to collect myself. When I later tried to explain how I felt, I couldn't hold back tears. Now I'm worried they think I can't handle the job and will fire me.
answer:
Thank you for sharing this with me. What you experienced sounds incredibly difficult and painful. It is completely understandable to feel hurt, embarrassed, and anxious after being publicly berated at work. Anyone in that situation would need a moment to collect themselves, and having an emotional reaction when you tried to address it later is a normal human response to feeling overwhelmed and disrespected. Please know that your feelings are valid.

First, I want to acknowledge the courage it took for you to try to explain how you felt to your supervisor. That is not an easy thing to do. Your worry about being perceived as unable to handle the job is a common reaction, but let's separate the event from your capability. A harsh, public reprimand is more a reflection of poor management and an unprofessional environment than a reflection of your competence or resilience.

From a practical standpoint, I encourage you to consider a few steps. If you feel safe to do so, you might request a private, calm follow-up conversation. You could say something like, "I'd like to discuss what happened the other day to ensure I understand your expectations moving forward." This frames it professionally. Document the incident, including date, time, witnesses, and what was said, for your own records. Also, please lean on your support system‚Äîfriends, family, or campus counseling services‚Äîto process this stress. Your university likely has free, confidential resources.

Your well-being is the priority. A workplace that uses humiliation as a management tool can be toxic and harmful to your mental health. If this behavior is a pattern, it may be worth considering if this job is a healthy environment for you. You deserve to work where you are treated with basic dignity and respect.

question: My partner constantly interprets my friendly interactions with colleagues as flirting, like when I compliment a coworker's idea in a meeting. It leads to accusations of infidelity almost daily, and they never acknowledge if they've overreacted. How can I make them see my intentions are purely professional?
answer:
Thank you for sharing this with me. I can hear how frustrating and hurtful this situation is for you. It sounds incredibly draining to have your professional conduct constantly questioned and to face daily accusations, especially when you know your intentions are genuine. Feeling misunderstood by your partner, particularly around something as fundamental as trust, is a very painful experience.

What you're describing goes beyond a simple disagreement; it points to a significant breach of trust and potentially deep-seated insecurities or anxieties within your partner. While it's understandable to want to "make them see" your perspective, this dynamic often becomes a cycle where explanations feel like defenses, and accusations continue. This is not something you can fix alone, as it resides within the relationship's dynamic and your partner's internal world.

My primary recommendation would be to seek couples counseling with a licensed therapist. A neutral professional can create a safe space for both of you to express your feelings. In therapy, your partner can explore the roots of their insecurity in a supportive environment, and you can both learn healthier communication skills. This pattern, if left unaddressed, can lead to increased control, isolation, and emotional harm.

For your own well-being in the meantime, I encourage you to maintain your professional boundaries and friendships. You have a right to a respectful work life. Please also gently reflect on whether these accusations are part of a larger pattern of controlling behavior. If you ever feel unsafe‚Äîemotionally or physically‚Äîprioritizing your safety and reaching out to a trusted support network or a domestic violence hotline is crucial.

You deserve a relationship built on mutual trust and respect. Taking the step toward professional help is a powerful way to care for both yourself and the future of your partnership.

question: My husband reads malice into my every action at work, such as getting upset if I have a late video call with a male team member. He's convinced I'm being unfaithful and never apologizes for the false accusations. What can I do to help him trust me and understand the nature of my job?
answer:
Thank you for sharing this with me. I can hear how hurtful, frustrating, and exhausting this situation must be for you. It's understandable to feel distressed when your professional commitments are misinterpreted and met with accusations, especially from your partner. You deserve to feel trusted and supported in your marriage and in your career.

What you're describing goes beyond typical workplace jealousy and enters the realm of damaging patterns of mistrust and control. His persistent accusations, lack of apology, and the reading of malice into your normal work actions are serious concerns. First and foremost, please know that his accusations are a reflection of his own insecurities or issues, not a reflection of your integrity or behavior. You cannot single-handedly "prove" your trustworthiness to someone who is unwilling to trust; that often deepens a cycle of needing to constantly prove yourself.

My primary recommendation, given the entrenched nature of this pattern, is to seek professional support. I strongly encourage you to propose couples counseling. A neutral therapist can facilitate a safer conversation where you can explain the demands of your job without it escalating into an accusation, and he can explore the roots of his insecurity. If he refuses to attend, I would suggest individual counseling for yourself. A therapist can help you establish healthy boundaries, communicate effectively under pressure, and navigate this dynamic for your own well-being.

In the immediate term, you might try a calm, scheduled conversation outside of any incident. Use "I feel" statements: "I feel hurt and undermined when my professional integrity is questioned. I am committed to our marriage, and I need us to find a way to rebuild trust." However, please be mindful of your safety. If these accusations ever escalate into verbal intimidation, threats, or attempts to isolate you from your work, these are red flags. Your safety and autonomy are paramount.

This is a difficult position to be in, but you are not alone. Seeking professional guidance is a courageous and constructive step toward healing, whether that healing happens together or individually.

question: I'm a project manager at a startup, and the constant pressure to meet unrealistic deadlines for low pay is making me feel burnt out and undervalued. How can I cope with this daily stress?
answer:
Thank you for sharing what you're going through. It takes courage to acknowledge feelings of burnout, especially in a high-pressure environment like a startup. What you're describing‚Äîfeeling constantly stretched thin, undervalued, and under-compensated‚Äîis incredibly draining, both emotionally and physically. Your feelings of stress and frustration are completely valid and a common human response to the situation you've outlined.

First, let's focus on some immediate coping strategies for the daily stress. I encourage you to build small, non-negotiable buffers into your day. This could be a five-minute mindfulness or breathing exercise before a meeting, a proper lunch break away from your desk, or a firm end-time to your workday to create separation. As a project manager, you might also practice "stress inoculation" by anticipating high-pressure moments and mentally rehearsing calm, assertive communication. Physically, prioritizing basic sleep, nutrition, and even short walks can significantly regulate your nervous system.

However, while coping mechanisms are essential, they don't address the root causes you've identified: unrealistic deadlines and low pay. This is where professional boundaries become crucial. I encourage you to prepare for a factual, solution-oriented conversation with leadership. Document specific examples of unrealistic deadlines and their impacts (e.g., on quality or team morale), and be prepared to propose adjusted timelines or necessary resources. Frame it from a perspective of sustainability and project success. If this feels too risky or if such conversations have failed before, it may be a sign to professionally evaluate your options elsewhere.

Burnout is a signal that your current situation is unsustainable. If these feelings persist or deepen, especially if you notice changes in sleep, appetite, or mood that concern you, I strongly recommend connecting with a therapist. They can provide dedicated support as you navigate these challenges. You deserve to work in an environment that values your well-being as much as your output.

question: As a junior lawyer at a demanding firm, I'm working extremely long hours without fair compensation, which is leaving me both exhausted and resentful. What steps can I take to handle this situation?
answer:
Thank you for sharing this with me. What you're describing sounds incredibly challenging, and it's completely understandable to feel both exhausted and resentful. The legal profession is known for its demanding culture, but working extremely long hours without fair compensation can lead to burnout and a deep sense of injustice. Your feelings are valid, and it takes courage to acknowledge them and seek a path forward.

First, let's prioritize your well-being. Chronic exhaustion isn't just an inconvenience; it can impact your mental and physical health. I encourage you to be gentle with yourself and consider integrating small, non-negotiable acts of self-care into your week, even if it's just a short walk or disconnecting for an hour. This isn't a solution to the systemic issue, but it's vital for maintaining your resilience while you navigate this.

From a practical standpoint, I recommend a two-step approach. Begin by gathering objective data. Document your hours worked, tasks completed, and the compensation (or lack thereof) for that labor over, say, the last two months. This creates clarity for you. Then, consider requesting a confidential meeting with a trusted mentor within the firm, a senior associate known for being reasonable, or your direct supervisor. Frame the conversation around your commitment to the firm and your career, and present your documented contributions. You could express your dedication while calmly stating the unsustainable nature of the current workload and its impact, and inquire about the path to fair compensation or adjusted expectations.

Please know that if the resentment and exhaustion are becoming overwhelming, seeking support from a therapist can be a powerful step. They can provide a confidential space to process these complex emotions and develop personalized coping strategies. You deserve a work environment that values your contributions and your humanity.

question: I was leading a project, but my manager reassigned key parts of it to a colleague. When I asked if this was due to my performance, I was told I was being overly sensitive and seeking too much validation.
answer:
Thank you for sharing this with me. I can hear how hurt and confused you are by this situation, and I want to start by validating that. Having key parts of a project you're leading reassigned can feel deeply undermining, and it's a very natural human reaction to seek clarity about the reasons behind it. Your question to your manager was a reasonable attempt to understand your professional standing, and being told you were "overly sensitive" or "seeking too much validation" likely compounded the hurt, making you feel dismissed. Your feelings are understandable and important.

When we experience something like this at work, it often impacts more than just the project‚Äîit can touch on our sense of competence, value, and security. It‚Äôs crucial to separate the *event* from your *worth*. The reassignment could be due to many factors‚Äîworkload redistribution, your colleague‚Äôs specific expertise, or even broader organizational shifts‚Äîthat aren't a reflection of your performance.

For practical next steps, I encourage a two-pronged approach. First, for your own well-being, practice some self-compassion. Acknowledge the sting, but also remind yourself of your proven skills and past successes. Second, consider requesting a follow-up conversation with your manager, framed collaboratively. You might say, "I've been reflecting on our last discussion and want to ensure I'm supporting the team's goals effectively. To help me grow, could you share specific feedback on my project leadership and how I can best contribute moving forward?" This focuses on growth and clarity, rather than validation.

If these interactions continue to feel dismissive or begin to create a hostile work environment, it may be helpful to document them and consider speaking with HR. Please know that if these feelings of being undermined persist and are affecting your mood or self-esteem significantly, seeking support from a counselor for ongoing coping strategies could be very beneficial. You deserve to work in an environment where your contributions are respected and your professional concerns are heard.

question: After a supervisor stepped in to handle a client I was managing, I expressed my worry that I had made a mistake. I emphasized my commitment, but was told I have a tendency to need excessive reassurance from authority figures.
answer:
Thank you for sharing this with me. It sounds like that was a difficult and vulnerable moment for you. It‚Äôs completely understandable to feel worried or unsettled after a supervisor steps in, and then to have your expression of concern met with that kind of feedback. Anyone in your position might feel a mix of professional anxiety and personal sting from that comment. I want to validate your feelings‚Äîthey are a normal reaction to a challenging workplace interaction.

Your emphasis on your commitment shows how much you care about your work and your clients, which is a real strength. The feedback about "excessive reassurance," while potentially difficult to hear, can also be viewed as a point for professional self-reflection, not a character flaw. Sometimes, patterns we develop in our communication style are rooted in a desire to do well and avoid errors, which is commendable.

As a next step, I encourage you to explore this with curiosity rather than judgment. You might ask yourself: In what situations do I feel the need to seek reassurance? Is it primarily with authority figures, or in high-stakes scenarios? A practical strategy could be to practice a brief, internal self-check before going to a supervisor. For instance, you could note: "Here is the situation, here is what I've done, here is my proposed solution." This can build confidence in your own judgment. If this pattern feels deeply ingrained or is causing significant distress, exploring it with a therapist could provide valuable insights into its origins and help you develop personalized coping strategies.

Remember, receiving constructive feedback is part of professional growth. How you choose to understand and work with it moving forward is what truly matters. You've shown great self-awareness by even asking this question.

question: I've been close friends with a female colleague for several years, and our connection has always felt a bit charged. We recently crossed a line and shared a kiss, agreeing to keep it between us. Even though we said it was a one-time thing, I can't stop thinking about what it meant. We still work on projects together remotely, and our friendly, flirty banter continues. She's very physically affectionate, which makes it harder for me to move on, even though she's made it clear she just wants to be friends. How can I stop hoping for more and preserve our important work friendship?
answer:
Thank you for sharing this with me. It takes courage to articulate such a complex and emotionally charged situation. What you're describing is incredibly common and understandably difficult. You're navigating a mix of genuine friendship, professional collaboration, and now, unrequited romantic feelings‚Äîall while trying to maintain an important working relationship. It's no wonder you're feeling stuck and preoccupied.

First, I want to validate that your feelings are completely normal. A significant, charged friendship that includes a moment of physical intimacy can create powerful emotional bonds and hope. The ongoing remote work and flirty banter, while perhaps meant platonically by her, understandably send mixed signals that keep those hopes alive. The core challenge here is the mismatch between your desire for more and her stated desire to remain friends.

To begin moving forward, we need to focus on what you can control: your own boundaries and interpretations. I gently encourage you to consider a few actionable steps:

1.  **Reframe the "Banter":** For your own emotional well-being, it may be necessary to consciously interpret her physical affection and flirty comments strictly as her platonic friendship style, not as potential signals. This is a mental discipline that takes practice.
2.  **Create Professional Distance:** During work hours and on work platforms, strive to keep interactions project-focused and cordial. It's okay to politely deflect or not engage in personal banter for a while. This isn't punitive; it's a protective measure for your heart.
3.  **Process the Hopes:** Find a healthy outlet for these feelings outside of your interactions with her. This could be journaling, confiding in a trusted friend (unconnected to work), or speaking with a counselor. You need a space to grieve the "what if" without it impacting your work dynamic.
4.  **Re-evaluate the Dynamic:** If, after setting these internal and professional boundaries, the friendship feels unsustainable or too painful, it is okay to let it naturally become a more distant, collegial relationship. Your emotional health is paramount.

This is a process, not a quick fix. Be patient and compassionate with yourself. If you find these feelings intensifying or affecting your work or overall well-being, seeking a few sessions with a therapist could provide dedicated support. You are taking the right first step by honestly confronting this situation.

question: For the past few years, I've developed a deep friendship with a coworker. There was always a subtle undercurrent of attraction, and a few months ago, we ended up sleeping together after a work event. We decided it was a mistake and to keep it professional, but I'm struggling to let go of my feelings. We're now in different departments, but we chat daily and have lunch sometimes. He's a naturally warm person and gives compliments that feel personal, leaving me confused. He's dating someone else now, but I catch him looking at me in a way that reignites hope. How do I accept the situation and get over my romantic feelings without losing his friendship?
answer:
Thank you for sharing this with me. It takes courage to articulate such a complex and emotionally charged situation. What you're describing is incredibly challenging‚Äînavigating deep feelings for a friend and colleague, especially after a shift in the physical nature of your relationship, is a painful and confusing experience. Your desire to both preserve a meaningful friendship and find peace for yourself is completely understandable, and your feelings of hope and confusion are valid given the mixed signals you've described.

The core difficulty here lies in the conflict between your emotional reality and the agreed-upon "professional" boundary. To move forward, you will likely need to create more space and clarity than currently exists. While daily chats and lunches maintain a close connection, they may also be inadvertently feeding the romantic feelings you're trying to release. I would gently suggest considering a temporary, intentional pullback in contact. This isn't about punishment or ending the friendship, but about creating the emotional distance necessary for your feelings to settle. You might reduce the daily chats to a few times a week and opt for group lunches instead of one-on-one for a period.

It is also crucial to examine his behavior through the lens of his stated commitment to being "professional" and his current relationship. A naturally warm demeanor can feel personal, but it may not signify a change in his intentions. Protecting your heart means accepting his actions at face value: he is a friend and colleague who is dating someone else. Redirecting the energy you spend analyzing his looks and compliments into nurturing other friendships, hobbies, or personal goals can be a powerful step toward acceptance.

Finally, please know that struggling to let go under these circumstances is very common. If you find these feelings persistently impacting your well-being or work, speaking with a therapist can provide a dedicated space to process this loss and develop personalized strategies. You deserve a relationship that is clear, reciprocal, and allows you to feel secure.

question: I've been struggling with my feelings for a colleague who is also a good friend. We've had a strong connection for a few years and shared a brief romantic moment, but it didn't progress. Now I'm pulling back and feeling confused about how to handle our work friendship.
answer:
Thank you for sharing this with me. It takes courage to acknowledge these complex feelings, especially in a workplace setting where the stakes feel so high. What you're describing‚Äîa strong connection, a shared history, and now this period of confusion and pulling back‚Äîis understandably challenging. It's natural to feel conflicted when deep friendship, romantic interest, and professional boundaries all intersect.

First, I want to validate your instinct to pull back and create some space for yourself. That is a wise and self-protective step when feelings become overwhelming. It allows you to gain clarity on what you truly need and want, separate from the daily interactions at work. This situation highlights the importance of professional and personal boundaries, which can become blurred in these circumstances. It might be helpful to gently assess what level of interaction you can maintain that feels respectful to your emotional well-being and your professional responsibilities.

As a practical step, consider setting some gentle internal boundaries for yourself. This could mean limiting one-on-one social interactions outside of work for a time, or consciously redirecting conversations at work to neutral, project-related topics. Journaling can be a helpful tool to untangle your feelings and identify any patterns. It's also crucial to nurture other parts of your life‚Äîyour friendships outside of work, hobbies, and self-care routines‚Äîto ensure this relationship doesn't become your sole emotional focus.

Given the complexity of navigating both a workplace and a close personal dynamic, if these feelings persist and cause significant distress, seeking a few sessions with a therapist could provide a confidential space to explore this more deeply. You deserve support in navigating this without having to manage it entirely on your own. Please remember, your feelings are valid, and prioritizing your emotional health is a sign of strength, not a detriment to your friendship or your professionalism.

question: There's a person at my job I consider a close friend, and I've developed romantic feelings for them over time. After a single intimate encounter that didn't lead to a relationship, I've started to create distance, leaving me conflicted and unsure how to move forward.
answer:
Thank you for sharing this with me. It takes courage to articulate such a complex and emotionally charged situation. What you're describing‚Äîdeveloping feelings for a close friend at work, navigating a shift after an intimate encounter, and feeling conflicted about creating distance‚Äîis understandably painful and challenging. It's completely normal to feel a mix of sadness, confusion, and even grief for the friendship as it was.

First, I want to validate your instinct to create some space. After a significant emotional event, giving yourself room to process is often a healthy form of self-protection. It allows your feelings to settle so you can discern what you truly need moving forward. The workplace dynamic adds a significant layer of complexity, as you must balance your emotional well-being with professional courtesy and teamwork.

A helpful first step could be to engage in some gentle self-reflection. When you feel ready, ask yourself: What is my primary goal? Is it to preserve the friendship, to move on completely, or to find a new, sustainable way to interact at work? There is no right answer, only what serves your long-term peace.

Given that this involves a workplace relationship, I must emphasize the importance of maintaining professional boundaries for your own protection and career stability. This can be incredibly difficult to navigate alone. If these feelings of conflict persist or begin to impact your work or overall well-being, I strongly encourage you to consider speaking with a counselor for ongoing, personalized support. We can explore strategies for compartmentalization, emotional regulation at work, and processing the loss of what you hoped the relationship could be.

You are navigating a very delicate situation with a great deal of self-awareness. Be patient and compassionate with yourself as you work through this.

question: My partner and I agreed to avoid explicit material, but his colleague keeps forwarding him suggestive memes at work. He feels it's awkward to set boundaries with a coworker, and I'm hurt he won't address it.
answer:
Thank you for sharing this with me. I can hear how hurt and frustrated you are feeling. It's completely understandable to feel that way when an agreement that is important to your relationship feels compromised, and when your partner's hesitation to address it leaves you feeling unheard. You've taken a significant step together by having that initial agreement, which shows mutual care and commitment.

Navigating boundaries at work can indeed feel very awkward and complex. Your partner may be worried about creating tension in a professional relationship or being perceived in a certain way. At the same time, his primary commitment is to your relationship. This situation presents an opportunity for the two of you to become a stronger team.

I would encourage you to approach this as a shared problem to solve, rather than you versus him. In a calm moment, you might express how the forwarded memes make *you* feel, using "I" statements, and then ask him how the situation with his colleague makes *him* feel. Explore the specific fears behind setting a boundary at work‚Äîis it about rejection, awkwardness, or professional repercussions? Together, brainstorm low-confrontation strategies he could use, such as simply not responding to that type of content, using a neutral reply like "Hey, let's keep the chat work-related," or adjusting notification settings. The goal is for him to take an action that honors your agreement, and for you to feel he is actively protecting your relationship's values.

If this pattern of difficulty with boundary-setting persists and causes significant distress, consider seeking a few sessions with a couples counselor. They can provide a neutral space to improve communication and develop effective strategies as a team. You deserve to feel secure, and your relationship deserves that protection.

question: My husband committed to my values about not consuming adult content. A teammate shared a risqu√© link in their group chat, and now he's defensive, saying calling out a peer would damage their professional rapport.
answer:
Thank you for sharing this with me. I can hear how distressing this situation is for you, and it makes complete sense that you would feel upset and conflicted.
